comment: Not my favorite but I have never had another like it. Mostly fruit, cherries, but not a lot else going on. Easy drinking, if the price was lower would be a good every day drink.
Should be a 1/2 star more. It's good...smooth but not terribly memorable.

Creamy and silky smooth. Vanilla, maple, and caramel are prominent. Cherries linger in the background with a touch of spice as the bourbon finishes on a whisp of oakey smoke. Not the most challenging of bourbons, but this is a wonderful affair to sip and enjoy at your leisure. Highly recommended as an after-dinner spirit.

Almost too smooth. Dried fruit (citrus?) on the nose. Vanilla, slightly warming on the palate. Very little burn, but just a hint of peppery rye on the finish. Very easy to sip. The critique at this price point is, without question, the lack of stand out taste.

I'm walking through a dark tunnel, following the scent of sweet orange. When I open my eyes, I find myself standing in the middle of an empty field.  There is nothing but dried dirt under my feet for miles, but when I close my eyes, I can smell traces of sweet orange everywhere. I should be disappointed, but for some reason, I'm just content at my heart.
I love this bourbon. I love the soft sweet taste to it. A great dram for when sitting back watching TV or enjoying the company of others.
My favorite of the three Orphan Barrel releases, although it's a bit muddled to me, honestly. I wouldn't buy it again.

I know the Orphan Barrel crew has been slammed for the marketing practices they have employed - but, in the end, it's all about what's in the bottle.  This is a very very nice bourbon.  Nice toffee and oak nose, lots of caramel and vanilla on the palate and touch of rye on the finish.  I highly recommend it.

This guy gets a bum rap because of the BS backstory.  I've really enjoyed it since the first couple of pours have let it breathe a little.  Toffee, oak and vanilla on the nose.  Oak, cinnamon and toffee on the palate.  Not much of a finish, but I'm still a huge fan.  Can't wait for the Lost Prophet to make its way to a store near me!

I like Rhetoric a tiny bit more but hell when it comes to a 20 year bourbon for around $75 count me in. Forget people talking trash about the Orphan Barrel project. It's a good bourbon, and if you're on the fence just go for it! I will probably buy one more bottle just to have for the future.
My favorite so far, have a bottle put away and wish I had more
Purchased in February 2015 from Michael towne wines for $80.

Thick vanilla cream and orange rind up front, followed by dried tropical fruits. The age doesn't really show itself off until the finish with oak and a touch of smoke, the finish is nice in length. A very nice whiskey, that aged gracefully.
Great bourbon for the price! Can't beat it when the bourbon is older then me!
Sweetness on the nose with a lot of charred oak taste. It is real smooth with some spice on the back. Nothing particularly outstanding but worth a try.
A qutie surprising bourbon with strong floral notes. Mainly camonmille
Smokey note. Strong kick. Warms your ass up
This is incredible.  Packs some serious heat, but is amazingly smooth
Great Bourbon. Nice complexity you should try.  Warm and smooth.
Vanilla and tasty. Ward's House of Prime for BK's party.
Very nice nose. Light and floral. A little on the taste. Not as robust as the nose.
Not too oakey and fairly smooth.  $75 for this was a good deal.
First pour you could smell and taste the vanilla and caramel, surprised by the burn and hot aftertaste, almost chalky. Now that it's open, I'll try it again in a couple days.

For a 20 year old bourbon, it's surprisingly NOT an absolutely over-oaked mess. Though, to be clear, it's still quite heavy on the oak. Without looking up the source of this juice, I'm guessing it's the Buffalo Trace distillery, because it's got a bit of that cherry/apple pie flavour I associate with BT/Eagle Rare. A lot of vanilla here, some custard, sawdust, pencil shavings, cherry liqueur. Slight nuttiness, in particular an almost candied nuttiness. A bit of citrus, like a charred orange peel. Quite dry, with a touch of maple syrup. Slightly chalky aftertaste. And surprisingly hot and alcoholic tasting throughout, considering the ABV and the time it was given to mellow in barrels. 
  
  On the one hand, it's a good-but-not-transcendent bourbon at a fairly high price. On the other hand, you're never going to find another 20 year old bourbon at this price-tag ($99 Canadian) or this easily available. So, ultimately a judgment call: personally, I'm not upset I made the purchase, and I'm glad to have tried a bourbon this old, but what it's ultimately revealed to me is what most distillers in the US have been saying for a long time: the current craze for hyper-aged stuff notwithstanding, bourbon *really* hits its sweet spot between about 8-and-12 years. Anything longer and you're looking at a bit of a gamble.
Sweet smooth dense on tongue. Delightful!
very tasty. big vanilla. would rate it a 4 if not for the price tag and stupid dancing fox.
Smooth rich limestone mineral and fuller bodied mouth with sweet cherry tart sour mingling with sweet charred oak and pecans with great tingling sensation and continuously drawing nose

This is awesome. I believe it should more appropriately be scored around a 92. 
      
      If you see it, buy it. 
      
      If around an ABC in Florida, ask the clerk. They tend to keep it hidden behind the counter, but it's no longer on their "lottery." 
      
      Happy hunting!
Biscuits and vanilla. Soft. Thin but not weak.

Nose: Vanilla, Maple, Oak, some slight char - fairly robust

Palate: Oak throughout, Sweet cherry, Candied fruits, nuttiness

Finish: Medium Long with nice tongue numbing but smooth, even warmth through your mid chest. 

Conclusion: Soft but Robust: full of flavor and easy to enjoy yet a bit of mystery. I believe the flavor will open up as it stays open. This. Is.  Fantastic.
Marketing ploy by diagio. Sourced bourbon that did nothing for me.

Quand même bon, par contre pour 97$ CAN je ne sais pas si ce bourbon à très bonne saveur de muscade en vaut le prix..... pour 20 ans âge le ''finish'' ne dure pas très longtemps en bouche. Bon, mais sans plus.
Found at Vicks, IN. Not tried.
Vanilla nose, good but not great

Nothing to get excited about.  Decent bourbon with soft vanilla and toffee flavors, very little oak considering it's age.  Much better bottles available for the money.  Maybe if they spent more on the bourbon and less on the marketing it would have rated better.
Great Mellow Tones of Vanilla and Oak
Very mellow vanilla and toffee flavor a with a mild burn at the end. Good bourbon but not good enough given the price.
Sweet vanilla with a lingering warmth
A delicious bourbon with a slight sweetness.  Very nice sipper.
Very supple, sweet and smooth. Tasty but lacks bite and character.
Little pricey but enjoyable.  I would recommend this to others.

Smells heavy and sweet, like maple syrup, with a hint of fruit. However, it feels thin on the tongue; this a light bourbon. Hints of wood, and wood cleaner or turpentine, some cacao bitterness at the end. Also, not as sweet as the nose suggests. Some warmth and numbing spice lingers, but the finish isn't that complicated. Definitely a pleasant sipper, but at this price you're justified in expecting some more. Hopefully this opens up with time. 3/29/17
  It hasn't been that long, and maybe I'm imagining this, but it does seem have to have developed a bit. Still has a very sticky, syrupy nose, but more vanilla this time around, along with a musky, sour note. A bit sweeter than I remember, but the wood and wood cleaner notes still seem to dominate the palate, and the back end is still spice and bitterness. Looking forward to future tastings. 4/16/17
  Three months later and this has really opened up. More vanilla, honey, and caramel. Still smooth, but more flavor. Some leather notes. Worth the wait. 7/3/17

So, despite my mostly disappointed experience with Orphan Gifted Horse, this bottle of 20 Year Old Barterhouse has been staring at me from atop the bar challenging me to redeem the Orphan Barrel/Diageo brand.  So, I caved in last night and popped the cork on another $90 "rescued" bourbon.

This offering comes in at 90.2 proof and is a nice, roasted caramel color while giving off hints of dark, roasted almonds and sweet, maraschino cherries on the nose.  There isn't much oak to be found.  That's kind of unexpected if this stuff has been truly resting for 20 years.

On the tongue, there's some cherry again along with a quite a lot of spicy, peppery oak.  That's it, though.  I expected a lot more complexity for sure.  Even the finish is a bit one-trick pony:  bitter burn.  I was hoping for some vanilla or something.  Nada.

Overall, it's better than Gifted Horse, but not by much and it certainly isn't worth $90+.  At this point, the only Orphan I've had that lived up to the hype was the 22 year old Rhetoric.  Good luck finding that, much less for a reasonable price.  3.25 stars.  Keep sippin' elsewhere my friends...
Really disappointing. The nose essentially ruins the experience with a heavy plastic/nail polish smell. For $100, I'd expect a bottle void of major flaws like this.

The aroma is of heavy nail polish, try sipping without smelling first, the aroma will throw off your palette, you can definitely tell a difference by smelling or not smelling first.  Straight- light peppery notes at first that quickly fades to a sweet vanilla flavor, warm finish that seems to lack depth.  Drops of water- still a spicy start that fades to vanilla but then some of the leather, oak, and smoke starts to come thru, much better depth.  This one really does respond well to a few drops of water.  Overall a nice 20 year that's just needs to be handled correctly, find the right amount of water and it will shine.
Honestly don't want to drink it again, which is ridiculous.  It's much lighter and brighter, sweeter than I want.
Nice, taste full body without burn. 90proof

A damn good pour. The nose has heavy marshmallow/vanilla. It's not as sweet tasting as the smell. A bit of leather and wood, the charred oak comes about 3/4 way through the sip. Definitely worth the $93 I spent. A very complex whiskey.

- Purchased at Stitzel-Weller Distillery in Louisville on August 12, 2017
- Tasted at home on August 12, 2017
- Maple; vanilla
- Nice sweetness
- Smooth; enjoyable
- Mash bill is 86% corn, 6% rye, 8% malted barley
Good hints of oak and vanilla. Don't put ice just drop of water

Light brown in color.
Smells like nail polish remover.
Smooth in mouth.
Very heavy burn upon swallowing.
Heavy char flavor.
Breathe out and get more burn.

Honey brown color that is somewhat lighter than expected. On the nose I get sweetness, caramel, mellow oak, vanilla and some faint heat. The palate is dominated by oak to an unpleasant degree. Some corn comes in at the end. The oak really washed out any other flavor to me, will try this one again after I let the bottle breathe for a while.
Reminded me a hair of old medical whiskey almost

Orphan Barrel Barterhouse
Bottle No. 18707
Classification: Kentucky Bourbon
Proof: 90.2 (45.1%)
Age: 20 Years
Mashbill: 86% Corn, 6% Rye, 8% Malted Barley
Distillery: Bernheim/Stitzel-Weller Distillery, Louisville, KY
Bottled: Orphan Barrel Whiskey Distilling Co., Tullahoma, TN
Price: $75
Color: Dark Copper
Nose: Vanilla, leather, hint of cherry, smallest hint of coffee
Palate: Smooth, burnt caramel sweetness, oak, cinnamon, char, vanilla, hint of dark cherry
Finish: Medium-Long finish, dry, oak, slight tannic bitterness, smoky, hint if dark chocolate
Personal Rating: 7.75/10
Notes: I really enjoyed this pour. While the oak is absolutely in the forefront of the flavor, it doesn’t overpower the drink. While it isn’t a complicated sip, it isn’t so simple that you won’t enjoy it. If I had one thing I would change, I think Barterhouse could benefit from a slightly higher proof. Perhaps the heat of around 55% alcohol would liven it up. I know some may think the Orphan Barrel project is kind of gimmicky, but I think it is a great idea. Otherwise we wouldn’t have access to solid bottles like Barterhouse. Given that the heat and spice level is low on this pour, go ahead and drink it neat. Might not be your favorite, but you would be hard pressed not to enjoy it
Oak and vanilla on the nose. Nice sweet front with a charred oak and slightly hot finish.
Lots of oak on the mid palate, sweet and caramel/vanilla.  Tasted over oaked to the tasting group, we all agreed we would not buy again, not worth $100...  another OB fail.

Another Orphan Barrel review following last nights "Gifted Horse". This is Barterhouse, a 20 year old Kentucky straight bourbon. Bottled at 45% ABV and is natural color of a dark copper. Most likely non chill filtered. 

Fairly sweet on the nose. Fruity. Apples, like straight out of the orchard. Dark berries and pineapple. A very light sensation of bubblegum and cotton candy. Very light oak, a little dill and nutmeg. Vanilla, cherries, corn and simple syrup. Not a very deep nose, light but pleasant. More woody/wood spices would have been a plus. 

Very sweet on the palate as well. Corn, cherries and a little pepper. Apple skin, baking spices, but missing the cinnamon, and a little caramel. No real complexity, especially for a 20 year old bourbon. 

Medium bodied mouthfeel that is a little thin. 
A medium long finish with corn and apples. 

I have to say I'm surprised by the underperformance by this bourbon. I would think that 20 years in a new oak barrel would have imparted much more flavor, especially in the oak department. It's all but missing any cinnamon or toffee. It's easy to drink, but for the age and the price of $80 locally, I would have expected some much more flavorful. Thanks again to Lee for supplying both of these Orphan Barrel whiskies, but I doubt I'll be trying any more in the future. 3.5
Cheers

Nose alcohol, apple,brown sugar
Taste leather, caramel,oak,
Finish slight burn in back of throat
Good, quality not equal to price.
Find this, taste this, buy this. I found it for 110$ US TO ME ITS WORTH 200$US

Nose - Intense dark caramel, dark chocolate, vanilla beans, sweet tanned leather, hint of coffee.

Taste - Tannic oaky sweetness, sweet dark caramel, hint of milk chocolate, like a slightly oaky dark chocolate covered Almond Roca candy, light cinnamon spice up front, light bitter oaked brown simple at the tail end as it goes down.

Finish - Drying oaky chocolate covered toffee, light oaky/almond skin bitter/sweet.

Score - 91/100

Final Thoughts - I hate to admit this but I'm actually a fan of this one. It has a lot of the flavors that I love in a bourbon which are dark chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Fantastic nose. I'm a fan of oak if it's balanced and this does it quite well. Reminds me of this one Woodford Reserve Double Oaked Single Barrel I had which I absolutely loved. A tiny bit more tannic than that one, but it hits all the right notes for me.

Would I drink it if offered? - Yes

Would I specifically order it? - Yes

Would I buy a bottle? - Yes, If the price was right.

Nose: Burnt plastic, burnt rubber, Oak, Touch of sweet
Flavor: Oranges, Grapes, Peaches, goes into char and oak and spice
Finish: Not super long spicy
12-4-18.    4.1  Very smoky nose but surprisingly smooth start to finish. Could have a little more bite but really nice.  For the price - would drink Bulliet Barrel instead.
Got to try this at a buddy’s house tonight. Very smooth, hints of pepper, spices, honey.
Spicy up front with lots of vanilla. Finishes with a nice sweetness
So smooth and unique flavor. Not overly oaky for 20 year. Butterscotch and warm biscuits. This is great. 4.5
Super unique taste. Enjoyed it a lot

Nose (3.75):  Very soft not alot going on here.  Maybe some carmel and maple syrup.  Not a bad nose but kind of just sits there.

Palate (4.25):  Maple syrup, pancakes, and butter.  I liked it.  Definately a sweeter bourbon but it tastes like a hearty breakfast.  It is not complex but it is inviting.  Much better than the nose.

Finish (4.0):  Leaves with a puff of smoke but not a natural smokiness.  Almost like that liquid smoke.  It is oaky and lingers but the "liquid smoke" kind of turned me off.

It isn't bad, not my favorite but I could see you liking it if you are in the mood to have your hotcakes and syrup in a glass.  20 years may have been too long in the barrel because this is a bit timid for me.  This would benefit greatly in a higher proof.  The flavors just are not there for me.
For sure a sweeter bourbon. A soft maple finish which I kinda like.

What a perfect, soft bourbon.  Admittedly, there is almost no hint of bite anymore, which might be a negative to some.  Nonetheless, I found this to be sweet and fruity almost like a bourbon crossed with port or sherry, almost like a hybrid product
Brown sugar smooth, sweet, smells good, dark cherry

The color is a beautiful rich dark copper. The nose had a nice combination of oak and dark fruits. The taste was consistent with the aroma. A nice surprise. These long aged bourbons can go either way; Better than I expected.
Delicious. Smells and tastes like you just walked into a rick house.

This is far more gentle and less oaky than I expected for a 20 year old bourbon. Classic notes of caramel, vanilla, honey and a bit of nuttiness to it. Like Walnut husks. This is an excellent dram and easy to sip on the deck

For the price tag I was expecting more but this is easy drinking and extremely well balanced. A lot of the usual bourbon notes...some wood, vanilla, a little caramel but not a ton. I like it but can’t believe the price tag. I should remove so points for that but since it’s my friend’s bottle I didn’t do the buying 🤷‍♂️

N: Caramel corn
P: Very sweet corn into cinnamon rye spice
F: Oak and char
Was hoping for more. Had it the evening after having one of the Bardstown series bottles which was very good. Nose is good but the taste isn’t as solid and falls short of the nose.
Not a fan of orphan barrel, but this was good
Oh shit! This is good! Tried blind against belle meade sherry and liked this more. Little more spice than expected.

This is actually the first time i have ever heard of the Orphan Barrels. It seems Diageo has some special, unique, "orphan" Barrels, that contain diferent whiskies from undisclosed distilleries. Actually a pretty good story, because they say that this are all very limited bottles and once they are gone, well... they aren't coming back.

Bottled at 45.1%abv,

Ok. The story is something. The tasting and nosing notes are another.

Caramel in the nose. Metallic coins, creme brulee. A little toffee. Vanilla. A little refined aroma notes. 

On the palate, very herbal and butterscotch. Apricots. 

Aftertaste is medium, long, very pleasant. It is a fine bourbon. But it is not a Pappy. Not a John E. Fitzgerald 20yo. Compared to those two, this one is fair. 85 over 100.
